caption: Actor Jaden Smith committed suicide in July 2016.

result.explanation: The image contains Will Smith and Jaden Smith.  The caption is factually incorrect; Jaden Smith did not commit suicide.

candidates.title: Jaden Smith Commits Suicide
candidates.content:
Claim:
Actor Jaden Smith committed suicide in July 2016.
Rating:
False
About this rating
In July 2016, news raced through social media that Jaden Smith, actor and son of Will and Jada Pinkett-Smith, had committed suicide:
The news was not true, and didn't come from a legitimate source. In fact, users who clicked the above-displayed message were greeted with a popup message requesting permission from a Facebook app to post on their behalf, making the article appear less like a hoax and more like an outright scam:
Messages about Jaden Smith's alleged suicide were shared from various sites, and led to a variety of dodgy-sounding Facebook apps, including "Smart Mobiles," "Gadgy Land," "Pakiza," "Top Feeds" and several others.
Intrepid internet users who clicked the link and gave the app permission were eventually greeted with one of several "news" story claiming that Jaden Smith had committed suicide. The web sites responsible for this hoax have published dozens of fake news stories and graphics with this false claim:
Users who granted these apps permission to post to Facebook on their behalf quickly found this death hoax posted to their own Facebook feeds, thereby replicating itself across social media.
Jaden Smith himself has been active on his social media accounts, seemingly unaware that he's supposed to be dead. He posted a photograph of himself on 27 July 2016:
candidates.description: A hoax article reported that the actor (and teenaged son of Jada Pinkett Smith and Will Smith) had killed himself.

result.explanation: The provided text from Snopes explicitly debunks the claim that Jaden Smith committed suicide in July 2016.  Snopes labels the claim as false, detailing how it originated as a hoax spread through social media and fake news websites.  The fact-check includes evidence of Jaden Smith's continued social media activity after the supposed date of his death.
result.supporting_points:
Claim: Actor Jaden Smith committed suicide in July 2016.
Rating: False
In July 2016, news raced through social media that Jaden Smith, actor and son of Will and Jada Pinkett-Smith, had committed suicide: The news was not true, and didn't come from a legitimate source. Jaden Smith himself has been active on his social media accounts, seemingly unaware that he's supposed to be dead. He posted a photograph of himself on 27 July 2016:

final_result.explanation: The caption "Actor Jaden Smith committed suicide in July 2016" is completely out of context with the provided image and is factually incorrect.  The image shows Will Smith and Jaden Smith together, appearing healthy and alive. This directly contradicts the caption's claim of Jaden Smith's death.  The internal check identifies this discrepancy with high confidence (confidence_score: 0).  The external check further reinforces this by referencing a Snopes fact-check that explicitly debunks the claim of Jaden Smith's suicide in July 2016. Snopes provides strong evidence showing the claim to be a hoax, citing Jaden Smith's continued social media activity after the alleged date of death (confidence_score: 10). There is no conflict between the internal and external checks; both strongly support the conclusion that the caption is false and out of context. The high confidence scores from both checks (0 and 10) converge to a strong conclusion that the claim is demonstrably false.  The image provides visual evidence of Jaden Smith being alive during or near the timeframe specified by the false caption.  The external fact-check adds further weight by tracing the origins of the hoax and presenting verifiable evidence contradicting the false claim.  Therefore, the final confidence score is set to 10, reflecting complete certainty in the conclusion that the caption is false and out of context.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external checks decisively refute the caption's claim, confirming its factual inaccuracy and lack of context.  The image shows Jaden Smith alive, and an external fact-check from Snopes labels the death claim as a hoax.
